channel.title: Drive Free Walks
channel.description: Do you love walking but find driving really stressful? This blog is all about walking without needing to drive to a great country walk. All the walks we do can be reached by bus or train.

item.title: Using the Traveline app to plan your walk
item.description:
The Traveline app is key ingredient to planning a drive-free walk.

Journey Planner

The journey planner naturally lets you type the start and end points for your journey. You only need a few characters before it starts to bring back the bus stops around the area.

Favourite Bus Stops

This is a great feature to help you locate bus times at your regular stops. Just select a stop and it will show you all the buses which are due to stop there in the next hour.

Bus Stop Finder

Have you ever not been able to find a bus stop. Sometimes they are not at the exact location on the route map or the stop on the return route may not be immediately opposite.

item.title: Bridging the Rhondda and Dare Valleys
item.description:
Starting at Cardiff Central, I took the 10:06 train to Treherbert. After passing through Pontypridd station I noticed when the train entered the Rhondda valley by station names like Trehafod, Porth, Tonypandy and Llwyn-y-pia. The train paused at Dinas Rhondda station as the double-track line reduced to single track. This required the driver to emerge from his cab to enter a small kiosk on the platform where he would phone for a token to allow the train to proceed on to the single track section. It only proved as a reminder to the lack of funding in Wales for a modern railway. A passenger arriving in Wales from London must feel like the Severn Tunnel is some kind of time warp!

The train passed through Treorchy, the home of the famous Male Voice choir. Just one stop at Ynyswen before the train finally reached the end of the track at Treherbert at the head of the Rhondda valley. From here, the track used to continue to loop around to the east to go under the mountains via the Rhonnda Tunnel which linked the Rhondda to the Llynfi valley. The tunnel is now buried and the track removed, although there are hopes that the tunnel can be reopened as a cycle tunnel.

The station at Treherbert was not typical of a terminus station - with only a ticket kiosk and toilets available for passengers. I walked straight on to the street to start walking through the streets of Treherbert. I headed towards Penpych mountain which is distinctive with its flat plateau summit.

item.title: Penarth Cliff-top walk
item.description:
Start: Penarth railway station. Distance: 4 miles (there and back).

Very close to Penarth station is the cliff-top walk which has excellent views across the Bristol Channel.

Today you could see Weston-Super-Mare, Avonmouth and both Flatholm and Steepholm islands.

Turning back at Lavernock Point you get views of The Victorian Penarth pier, Cardiff and Neeport docks.

item.title: Lunch-time walk in Bute Park
item.description:
One of the great things about working in the centre of Cardiff is being able to walk around Bute Park in my lunch break.

I have experience the bare branched trees in the winter, blossoming trees in the spring, luscious green leaves in the summer and beautiful oranges and browns in the autuumn.

item.title: Lunch-time Walks...
item.description:
Do you work in a city centre?

Do you feel lethargic sitting at your desk all day without getting any exercise? I enjoy my lunch-time walks around Cardiff city centre. I vary the routes daily so that it does not become too routine – just in case people start waiting for me on every Wednesday afternoon saying “oh look he’s about to pass again!” My usual walk is down Queen Street, High Street and St. Mary Street, around the St. David’s Centre and then back up Churchill Way. One variation is simply the reverse route which is great when walking up St. Mary Street towards the gates of Cardiff Castle. Another route is around the City Hall and National Museum area.

If I have sufficient flexi-time, then I venture into Bute Park for a stroll down the Taff trail. I am planning some future walks making use of trains and buses by travelling one stop down the line and walking back to the office. These are some of my future walking routes to try by train…

  • Train to Cardiff Bay and walk back along the Atlantic Wharf dockside.
  • Train to Heath High Level and walk back through Roath Park, then down Crwys road and City road.
  • Train to Grangetown and walk back into the city centre.
  • Walk through Bute Park to Llandaff and catch the bus back to the office.
  • Take the bus up Cowbridge road to Victoria Park and walk back.

I hope to promote these on the health & wellbeing section of the office intranet to try and entice some staff to join me.

Do you have any favourite lunch-time walks around your office? Let us know by posting a comment below…

item.title: 10 Drive-free Buggy Walks in South Wales
item.description:
Here are some great walks which are suitable for buggies and wheelchair users. All are fully accessible by public transport, so if you would like to explore a different area just hop on a bus or train to walk in a different area. The following areas are ideal for planning walks from one to six miles.

  1. Bute Park is just a short walk up the river Taff from Cardiff Central station. Stretching from Cardiff Castle to Pontcanna, the park contains open spaces, good surfaced paths and many species of trees giving it status as an arboretum. There are bus links all around the park so there are options for both linear and circular routes.

  2. Grangemoor Park is a disused landfill site which has been covered with clay and turned into a nature reserve. Take the bus to Cardiff Bay Retail Park which runs parallel to one edge of the park. From the highest point, you are rewarded with a 360 degree view including the Senedd, the Millennium Stadium, the Barrage and St. Augustine’s church on Penarth Head. The Ely river runs by on one side of the park, so if you feel like a longer walk you can follow Ely Trail as far as the next retail park at Leckwith.

  3. Roath Park is a thin strip of land containing a Victorian boating lake. The Scott memorial stands proudly at the head of the lake to commemorate the ill-fated Antarctic expedition. There is a children’s adventure play area, a botanical garden and a natural woodland area at the far side of the lake. There are bus stops all around the park which make it easily accessible from the city centre.

  4. Cosmeston Lakes Country Park is located just to the south of Penarth. Originally an old quarry works, the twin quarries have now been filled with water to create a beautiful lakeland environment both for humans and for wildlife. You can walk around both lakes, complete a figure of eight or just relax on the grass feeding the ducks. If you fancy a trip back in time, there is a life-size replica of a 14th century Medieval Village which you can walk around and experience how our ancestors used to live.

    To get there, take the #94 bus to Barry via Sully and alight right outside the main entrance to the park which is shortly after the Harvester pub.

  5. Swansea Bay is the gateway to the Gower peninsula. The steel works of Port Talbot lie on one side, facing the tourist attractions of Mumbles on the other with the city of Swansea in the centre. From Swansea railway station, head out of the city centre to the the Marina to find the start of the cycle trail. The cycle trail was built on the former route of the Swansea to Mumbles tramway which is famous as the first passenger rail service. The views are staggering as you look ahead to Mumbles point with the pier and lifeboat station stretching out into the bay.

    The path to Mumbles is five miles long, but if you don’t feel you can walk the entire return trip, there are frequent bus stops along the main road running back to the city centre.

  6. Forest Farm Nature Reserve is a haven for several species of birds along one of the last remaining stretches of the old Glamorganshire canal which transported coal from the Valleys to Cardiff docks. Take the train to Radyr station, cross over the footbridge over the river and continue to head into Forest Farm. The Melingriffith feeder canal runs parallel to the main canal before heading off to link with the river. The canal continues through the woodland, passing through the ruins of an old lock before finally being cut off by the M4. Herons, kingfishers and families of ducks make this a popular destination for photographers.

  7. Treforest to Llantrisant is an east to west linear walk linking the Taff Valley to the foot of the Rhondda Valley. There are spectacular views of Cardiff and the Vale of Glamorgan as the path runs parallell to the coastline. Take the #132 Stagecoach bus from Cardiff to Treforest, and return on the #122 bus from Talbot Green Retail Park at Llantrisant. The total length of the path is 6 miles, but you can always break the walk in Llantwit Fardre and take a bus to Pontypridd or Llantrisant.

  8. Barry Island used to be the location for the only Butlins Holiday Village in Wales. Now closed and the land redeveloped as housing, Barry Island is the closest sandy beach to Cardiff. The train runs all the way from Cardiff to the island. Walk along the promenade, passed the coffee shops and arcades to proceed out to the head point of the bay.

    In recent years Barry Island has received a massive boost to its tourism value owing much gratitude to the Gavin and Stacey sitcom. During your walk, try to see how many references to the show you can spot. Relax with a coffee or ice cream at Marco’s cafe but you’ll be lucky if you are served by Joanna Page (aka Stacey)!

  9. Taffs Well to Caerphilly is a small section of the Taff Trail which runs for 55 miles from Brecon to Cardiff. The village of Taffs Well sits in between the Garth and Caerphilly mountains. Infrastructure planners have fully taken advantage of the break in the high-level land created by the river. Routes through the pass include a dual carriageway road and a double-track railway. Another railway also used traversed the valley on the Walnut Tree viaduct, of which only one full pylon remains today.

    Take the train to Taffs Well and the Taff Trail (route 8) is well signposted opposite the main car park of the station. There is a gentle gradient up hill, so be wary of cyclists free-wheeling downhill in the opposite direction. When you reach the outer suburbs of Caerphilly, you can choose to continue on the east-west Celtic Trail (route 4) which will take you into the town centre. The town centre is dominated by an impressive castle with a moat and drawbridge. Also look out for the statue of Tommy Cooper who was born in Caerphilly – just like that!

  10. Risca to Crosskeys is a recently surfaced path running alongside a branch of the Brecon and Monmouthshire canal which runs from Crumlin to Newport. Risca is located at the start of the Ebbw valley. The town has experienced a lot of growth caused by its proximity to both Newport and Cardiff. From the railway station at Risca follow the signs for the canal which runs on an embankment above the town. This makes for lovely views the valley to your left. You may be passed by several mountain bikers as they make their way to and from the off-road trails of Cwmcarn Forest Drive.

item.title: Radyr to Coryton, the Missing Link
item.description:
Start: Radyr railway station End: Coryton railway station Distance: 3 miles

Radyr is a picturesque village situated near the edge of a cliff over the river Taff. Before the decline of the coal mining industry in South Wales, Radyr was one of the largest rail hubs in the area allowing coal trains from the Valleys to be re-routed between Cardiff, Penarth and Barry docks. Now it is the junction point for the main Valley routes and the local City Line service. The site of the old sidings has now been redeveloped into residential properties, though there are many remnants from the old railway days to be found in the area.

The route of this walk will actually close off the C-shaped route of the City Line train route to Coryton, by exploring the Forest Farm Nature Reserve, the Glamorganshire canal and a disused railway line to Coryton station. Although from the map, the walking route is more like an S-shape.

Take the train from Radyr railway station to walk via Forest Farm to Coryton station.

As you head out of the station car park, take the steps down to the road and turn left to pass under the railway. Continue on and turn right through a kissing gate, the walk down the road to the Cricket Club.

The footpath passes in front of the clubhouse on the edge of the field so watch out for sixes if there is match being played! In the corner climb over into a lovely wild meadow. Here you have a choice of either following the path along the river’s edge or you can cut off the bend by taking a shortcut diagonally across the meadow to the railway bridge.On the other side of the river, continue down the path alongside the back of houses to emerge by the Melingriffith water pump. This water pump has recently been restored. Its original purpose was to pump water from the feeder canal to supply the main canal. Turn left to walk on the pavement until you see the entrance to the Glamorganshire canal on the other side of the road. The route now takes you between the main canal and the feeder canal, which makes for a very beautiful walk in all seasons. There is also plenty of wildlife and birds to spot. If you are lucky then you may see a few kingfishers. Where the path splits, continue on the right to go passed an abandoned lock. The path ends at a second lock where the M4 motorway has been built across the canal, forcing it to pass through a tunnel to reach Tongwynlais. Walk across the tunnel entrance to ascend steps to the top of the cliff.

At the top of the cliff you will find a tall arched bridge spanning a disused railway cutting which has again been blocked off by the M4. Descend down into the cutting and follow the old trackbed all the way to an identical arched bridge. Just cross over the road to reach Coryton station.

item.title: A Scenic walk from Cardiff Central to the Bay
item.description:
Start: Cardiff Central – main Wood St. entrance.

End: Cardiff Bay station

Distance: 2.7 miles

A scenic walk following the river Taff from Cardiff city centre to the bay. This is a lovely walk leaving the centre of Cardiff and following the final section of the Taff trail to the modern developed area of Cardiff Bay, formerly known as Tiger Bay when it was one of the busiest coal mining ports in the world. Now it has been redeveloped into a mecca for fine dining, high-class living, entertainment and a business hub.

Starting from the main line railway station, this walk will take you on a slightly less urban to the waterfront area of Cardiff Bay. The route starts by crossing the river to follow the Taff trail south in the edge of Grangetown, home to some of Cardiff’s ethnic minority communities and a regular filming location for Doctor Who and Casualty. Most of the opposite bank of the river is taken up by the Brains brewery, the local beer for the Cardiff and much of the South Wales area.

Follow the Taff trail until you reach the Penarth road bridge opposite Big Yellow Self-Storage. Cross the road at the pedestrian crossing and continue until you reach the Clarence bridge, where you should cross the road and turn left across the bridge. Take the next right to follow the road along the opposite bank of the river. At the end of the road, go through the turnstile gate into Hamadryad Park. You now have the option of taking the direct route straight across the park or a slightly wider loop around the edge – both will emerge at another gate underneath the dual carriageway flyover.

Follow the path up to cross over the roundabout at the entrance to the yacht club, then enter the Cardiff Bay Wetlands area. This area has been designated to protect all the natural wildlife of the bay which has been established since the construction of the Barrage which caused the conversion of the area from a saltwater estuary to a freshwater lake. You will exit the wetland area into the car park for the St. David’s Hotel which is one of the iconic landmarks for Cardiff Bay due to its impressive sail-design roof. Walk through the car park and carry on until you reach the dockside of one of the remaining docks.

As you walk along the dockside, you will notice tracks in the paving which were used by loading cranes to move up and down the dock. Some of the cranes have been left in place to commemorate the former use of the area during the boom times of the coal industry. At the end of the dock, follow the path around the dock to the right, walking passed Techniquest and the end of another dock and into the Mermaid Quay district of cafes, bars, restaurants, galleries and shops. A common meeting point for groups is outside the Terra Nova bar, named after the ship which sailed Captain Scott and his crew on their ill-fated expedition to Antarctica. Its worth exploring the interior of the bar which is furnished as though it were an old sailing ship.

From the Terra Nova, continue to walk along the quayside until you reach a footbridge over the Oval Basin which was created out of an old dock. This is where many seasonal events are held throughout the year. It is also often referred to as “Torchwood HQ” after the fictional TV series had based its main base underneath it. Walk across the bridge towards the red brick Pierhead Building. If you walk around the front of the building you will see the Senedd, the debating chamber for the Welsh Assembly. All the slate used in building the Senedd was mined in the North Wales slate mines. Now walk on the left side of the Senedd to face the side entrance of the Wales Millennium Centre which is used for concerts, plays, operas and a whole variety of other shows.

To return to Cardiff Central, there is a regular bendy-bus service from the bus stops next to the Millennium Centre. If you prefer the train, then cross the road and continue walking along the pedestrian area until you see Cardiff Bay station ahead.

item.title: Group discounts for rail and bus travel
item.description:
If you are walking with a few friends then it may appear more expensive to travel by train than by contributing to a car share. However many train operators give discounts for fare prices for small groups of 3, 4 or more people and also for larger groups of 10 or more.

Arriva Trains Wales offer a 25% discount on individual tickets when travelling in a small group within their own network. Please see their group travel policy:-

Cardiff Bus offer group travel on Sundays and evenings for £6 if you are in a group of 4 people. This would make it relatively cheap for four people to meet in the centre of Cardiff to travel by bus to Wenvoe, to walk through the Vale’s picturesque scenery to Barry Island for some coastal scenery before taking a return bus to Cardiff.

item.title: Bute Park Horseshoe
item.description:
Start: Cardiff Central – main Wood St. entrance.

End: Cathays station.

Distance: 3.4 miles. A refreshing walk around the Bute Park arboretum.

Bute Park is Cardiff’s answer to Hyde Park in London and Central Park in New York, providing green open spaces for city dwellers to walk, cycle, run and play. The river Taff flows along the park’s border giving an idyllic riverside experience.

Exit the rail station on the left and cross over the road at the pedestrian crossing. After crossing the river Taff, turn right to follow the Taff trail along the Taff Embankment northbound. The Millennium stadium on the opposite bank is the home ground of the Wales rugby team with a seating capacity for 80000 people. Continue walking passed the Nos Da hostel/bar as the path inclines slightly to join a gravel path. This will take you underneath the Cowbridge road bridge and into Sophia Gardens on the other side. Note that the path under the bridge may be impassable when the water level is high, so you may need to use the pedestrian crossing on the road above.

Follow the path up to the Millennium Footbridge which is one of the entry points into Bute Park on the other side of the river, however this route will continue along the western bank passed the Swalec Cricket stadium, through Pontcanna Fields to cross over at the Blackweir foot bridge. This bridge is suspended so it has a tendency to sway if there is too much movement or weight on it! Blackweir is the first of three weirs in the tidal section of the river, the other two being at Llandaff and Radyr. It is a popular spot for picnics, fishing and swimming in the summer months. After crossing the river, turn right through the iron gate to enter Bute Park from the northern entrance. From this point, you can choose to either continue along the tarmac path or take the narrower path through the woods. If you follow the main path, then you will see some impressive wood-carved sculptures out of fallen and standing tree trunks. The main path will meander around the edge of rugby fields to bring you to the Arboretum area of the park which is host to a various species of trees. Once again, you have the option of walking amongst the trees and reading the information panels. Return to the main path on the eastern side of the Millennium Footbridge where there is an outdoor cafe/bistro. Following on the same side of the river, the path passes through the cultivate section of the park which is very colourful in the summer months. When the path reaches forks, take the left-hand fork to cross Cooper’s Field which is sometimes the location for a circus, the Eisteddfod and other events. On the right side of the path, there is a stone circle, though on a much smaller scale than Stonehenge. Continue to follow the path in the same direction, passing the walls of Cardiff Castle on your right, to exit the park at the eastern gate.

Turn right to go down into the subway under the dual carriageway to emerge outside the Law Courts. Continue again to pass in front of the City Hall with the dome and then the National Museum of Wales. Cross over the road and walk along Park Place, passed the Students Union until you reach Cathays station.
